Remembrance Day: activities and reading to get your child thinking

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Nov 9, 2015

Try these books, websites and colouring activities to get your child thinking about Remembrance Day:

Reading War

Reading War is an online resource from publisher Barrington Stoke which is packed with information on World War I and explores war themes in two very different very novels.

Tilly’s Promise by Linda Newbery

The introduction to Tilly’s Promise is right in pointing out that “when we think of the First World War, we think of trenches and soldiers, guns and shells and gas attacks. But the War affected everyone in Britain, including those at home.”

The book is about a young nurse called Tilly and her brother with learning difficulties who is called up to fight at the front line. Tilly tries to protect her brother, but can she save him?

There are lots of interesting interactive elements on their microsite, including a video of the author reading the first chapter (which you can alternatively read yourself) and an embroidery activity.

Over the Line by Tom Palmer

Did you know that the player who scored England’s first international goal after World War One was a survivor of the trenches?

Set in 1914, this book focuses on a young man called Jack making his debut as a pro footballer. However, as the war drags on, Jack is thrown into a nightmare world he will be lucky to survive.

The microsite has lots of amazing stuff that will entertain young people who are into football. There’s information, quizzes, videos about the trenches and you can even listen to author Tom Palmer reading the first chapter of Over the Line!

You can find more reading inspiration for children and young adults about WWI and WWII in our Remembrance Day book list.

History Alive

The Imperial War Museum has some brilliant online resources to explore, including sections on World War Two posters and an audio-visual, interactive tour of a traditional 1940s house.

Colouring Activities

The Royal British Legion has produced the following colouring sheets in PDF format, ready to print.

  • Poppies
  • Remembrance Cross
  • Medals

See more posts like this at Beyond the Book, Matt’s blog about his travels as our literacy ambassador.

Matt Shenton

I’m the Literacy Ambassador for Suffolk Libraries. Follow my travels around the glorious county of Suffolk @mjes
